DR. MILES AWARDED
MEDAL OF HONOR
Major McKinney Comments on
His Bravery in Armistice
Day Speech
HIGHEST HONOR
R. 0. T. C. Unit Presents Arms
In Memory of War
Heroes
Major McKinney addressed the
R. 0. T. C. students in a Memorial
speech delivered last Monday, Armistice Day, in which he commented on Captain Miles' bravery
during the late war. The whole
unit, after having their pictures
taken for the Hullabaloo, was lined
up in front of the Gillman Hall
steps and listened to the address.
After it was over they were dismissed for the day. The following
is a resume of Major McKinney's
speech.
Speech
"It is fitting that we of the
R. 0. T. C. Unit Should pause in
our work on this ,the eleventh anniversary of the signing of the Armistice, and consider what memories of those days eleven years ago
we should cherish. We_know that
many made sacrifices some giving
their lives, for a cause that meant
something great to them. It seems to
me that the thing which we should
particularly cherish and keep alive
in our country is the spirit in which
these sacrifices were made. Those
men were urged forward by an
interest greater than prsonal consideration. And it is indeed a sublime
spirit which makes us "lose ourselves in something greater than
ourselves."
"I think it is proper on this occasion to cite the example of a
Hopkins man (now one of your
professors) as indicated in the citation given him in awarding him the
Medal of Honor, the highest
decoration given by our Government for bravery in action. This
man is L. Wardlow Miles, and his
citation reads. as follows: (I should
add that this is being read without
without his knowledge—
Citation

Miles, L. Wardlaw
Near Revillon, France
September 14, 1918.
R—Princeton, N. J.
B—Baltimore, Md.
Captain, 308th Infantry,
77th Division.
Congressional Medal of Honor.
Volunteered to lead his company
in a hazardous attack on a commanding trench position near the
Aisne Canal, which other troops
had previously attempted to take
without success. His company immediately met with intense machinegun fire, against which it had no
artillery assistance, -but Captain
Miles preceded the first wave and
assisted in cutting a passage through
the enemy's wire entanglements. In
so doing he was wounded five times
by machine-gun bullets, both legs
and one arm being fractured;
whereupon, he ordered himself
carried forward to the enemy trench
in order that he might encourage
and direct his company, which by
this time ha:d suffered numerous
casualties. Under the inspiration
of this officer's indomitable spirit,
his men held the hostile position and
consolidated the front line after an
action lasting two hours, at the conclusion of which Captain Miles was
carried to the aid station against
his will.
"In concluding these brief exercises let our thoughts turn to those
who made the supreme sacrifice.
We would be untrue to • their
memory if we did not cherish with

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 15, 1929

GRADUATE STUDENT
DANCE TONIGHT
Tonight a Graduate Students' Dance will be held in
Levering Hall from nine to
twelve. Graduate students,
faculty members and their
wives are invited to.- attend.
A radical departure will be
adopted in the running of the
dance. No tickets for the
dance are being sold. Funds
to cover the expenses of the
dance will be collected indirectly. Boxes will be placed
at the doors and guests may
pay as they leave the hall.
This dance will be a forerunner to future affairs the graduate students have planned.

HARRIERS TO
RUN ST. JOHNS
Entry in Middle Atlantic Meet
Canceled
VICTORY EXPECTED
Sport New at Annapolis Instition
Since the Black and Blue's entry
into the Middle Atlantic CrossCountry meet has been called off
due to the ineligibility of Scheibel
and Packard, the Hopkins harriers
will meet the St. John's team this
Saturday instead. This arrangement will give the harriers a ten day
rest for the Maryland meet which
will take place Tuesday 26, at
Homewood field. The strength of
the St. John's team really cannot
be estimated, for this year they are
turning out their first regular team.
The meet will take place on the
Hopkins' four and one-half mile
course. It will start during the first
quarter of the St. Johns-Hopkins
football game and will end sometime between the halves. Kelly
says, "We expect the meet to be
over in twenty-seven minutes if possible." The football game together
with the harrier meet will make a
real St. John's-Hopkins day out of
this Saturday. Kelly expects the
same men to run who beat Catholic
University last week. Hancock
will probably be used if his foot
gets into shape by that• time.
The Saturday following St.
Johns will meet Maryland and two
days before Thanksgiving the Hopkins harriers will meet Maryland at
Hopkins. This will be the last
meet of the season for Hopkins and
Coach Hambleton is very hopeful
of the results. Maryland beat us
last year and we beat them the year
before. It has been alternating
thus for a number of years. This
year it is our turn to win if the
law of averages holds true. This
meet will be, it is expected, a replica of the conquest over the Catholic
University, for the boys know the
course and are still full of pep due
to the past victory.

at-Lehigh, much to the approval of
the frosh. Several other universities have adopted much less astringent methods of the imposition
of the regulations than were hitherto observed. However this does
not mean to sdy that Freshman
regulation in general will disappear
entirely, as they have here at
Hopkins. Such organizations as
the Student Councils, Sophomore
Councils, etc., have been put in
charge of seeing that the regulations
are still observed. In case of refractions of any of the rules, the
guilty party is usually made to
appear before the council bodies.
It is greatly to be regretted that
hazing is declining as an institution,
for it was not only a colorful one
and one that was enjoyed by Freshmen (at least those who took it as
good sports), but it was a continued
source of amusement to upperclassmen. Freshmen here at Hopkins
stroll around the campus as if they
owned the place, and seem to show
little respect for the lordly upperclassmen. In other words they are
not learning the first law which
should apply to freshmen—humility.

Mr. Duer to Address
Engineers Clubs
Tonight, there will be a joint
meeting of the Engineers Clubs, at
which the A. I. E. E., the A. S.
M. E., the A. S. C. E., and the
S. I. E. are to be represented. This
will be held in the C. E. Building,
at 8:15 according to F. A. Allner,
Chairman A. S. M. E. and Chairman W. B. Kouwenhoven of the
A. I. E. E.
Mr. J. V. B. Duer, Electrical Engineer of the Pennsylvania Railroad, will speak on the "Electrification of the Pennsylvania Railroad." This topic is a very important one and of great interest, not
only to Baltimore Engineers and
engineering students, but also to the
public. Mr. Duer is an excellent
speaker and he will illustrate his
talk with lantern slides. Everyone
is invited to attend this lecture.

EDITORIALS

VICTORY IN DEFEAT
we have allowed the football season to pass by without
U the customary
editorial exhorting the team to victory and all that
P to now

sort of thing. The reason should be obvious, for no mere words of
ours would have done the slightest bit of good. There is no use denying that this is an off year, that our football team has been competing
far out of its own class and, naturally, the results have been disastrous.
We must simply accept conditions as they are. Every college has one
or two famine seasons such as Hopkins is now passing through. The
coaches are helpless to change things and must use the material available to the best advantage even though the finished product may be
an uncoordinated machine.
As for the team itself, it probably feels its own incapabilities rather
seriously. To go into game after game and to be turned aside like
leaves in the path of an autumn wind is no cheerful experience. It
requires more pluck and,fight to go into a contest against opponents
whom you know to be far superior than to play on even footing. A
team, which week after week can play a fighting game in the face of
tremendous odds and yet not give way entirely, deserves some sort of
praise. We Americans are much too prone to hero worship. We
glorify the victor no matter how his victory was won and turn a "cold
shoulder" to the conquered victim. Yet often, the victor does not
deserve the praise as much as the victim who may, though losing,
gather more glory to himself than if he had won. We are not claim• ing glory for the Hopkins team, but only trying to make you realize
that our team, though it has lost all but one game and has had tremendous scores rolled up against it, nevertheless deserves praise for
fighting a losing battle gamely. It is no encouraging prospect for
those eleven men to go out every Saturday faced with a hopeless task.
Tomorrow, we meet an ancient rival who has a team, which, while
not equal to its best, is yet far superior in comparison with our own.
There is no use fooling ourselves that we will be, even approximately,
on an even footing with St. John's tomorrow afternoon. We can only
hope that the team will go out determined to fight as hard as it can
and play the best brand of football of which it is capable. No victory is expected, but Hopkins teams have a reputation for fighting hard
and making the best of all the "breaks" so that the unexpected is by
no means impossible.
More important than a victory is that the team shall play fairly and
squarely. We on the sidelines will be back of you in so far as our
vicarious participation may be of any help. What we most desire is
to see a good game. If you win we shall be happy in victory, but if
you lose, your defeat will not be any disgrace so long as you go down
fighting as onlyHopkins' teams can.

Students at Kansas Weslyan
capered over the campus bedecked
as hoboes recently in anticipation
of the Coyote-Swede game. The
festivities began at four-thirty and
lasted all day long. Freshmen who
did not appear in the proper (or
rather, improper) attire were subject to the Sophomore's paddles.
The hoboes had a parade through
the town later in the day.

in Canada and will be in operation
in about four or five years. The
stadium will be built in the shape
of a horseshoe.

Regardless of the Editor's opinion of the journalistic talents which
I have exhibited in "pinch hitting"
for Gump, the editorial column of
a paper is no place to indulge in
purely personal attacks such as Mr.
Bloom permitted himself to do. My
editorial was purely a matter of attacking a policy which the Y.M.
C. A. has adopted and made no
reference to the individuals who are
responsible for this policy. I need
make no apologies for my literary
ability nor make any claims for it,
nor does the sarcasm of Mr. Bloom
affect me in the least. I haven't
noticed as yet that he has gathered
any laurels for himself as a critic
nor can I understand by what right
he presumes to set himself up as a
judge of anyone's ability. Whatever his personal opinions on the
subject may be, he is not privileged
to use the name of the "Y" as the
official champion of his views.
THE NEWS-LETTER is no battle
ground for mud-slinging, and I am
more than surprised that the supposedly gentlemanly members of
the Y. M. C. A. would permit their
paper in its official utterances, to
be used for any such unethical
purposes.

California, completed plans on September 12th
to build a new tinplate plant. On the 13th
they gave an order to Westinghouse for two
5,000 horsepower synchronous motors to drive
the rolls, to be physically the largest synchronous motors ever built. Delivery of
the first was wanted in ninety days.

design, manufacture, assem-

HIGHEST HONOR
R. 0. T. C. Unit Presents Arms
In Memory of War
Heroes
Major McKinney addressed the
R. 0. T. C. students in a Memorial
speech delivered last Monday, Armistice Day, in which he commented on Captain Miles' bravery
during the late war. The whole
unit, after having their pictures
taken for the Hullabaloo, was lined
up in front of the Gillman Hall
steps and listened to the address.
After it was over they were dismissed for the day. The following
is a resume of Major McKinney's
speech.
Speech
"It is fitting that we of the
R. 0. T. C. Unit Should pause in
our work on this ,the eleventh anniversary of the signing of the Armistice, and consider what memories of those days eleven years ago
we should cherish. We_know that
many made sacrifices some giving
their lives, for a cause that meant
something great to them. It seems to
me that the thing which we should
particularly cherish and keep alive
in our country is the spirit in which
these sacrifices were made. Those
men were urged forward by an
interest greater than prsonal consideration. And it is indeed a sublime
spirit which makes us "lose ourselves in something greater than
ourselves."
"I think it is proper on this occasion to cite the example of a
Hopkins man (now one of your
professors) as indicated in the citation given him in awarding him the
Medal of Honor, the highest
decoration given by our Government for bravery in action. This
man is L. Wardlow Miles, and his
citation reads. as follows: (I should
add that this is being read without
without his knowledge—
Citation

Miles, L. Wardlaw
Near Revillon, France
September 14, 1918.
R—Princeton, N. J.
B—Baltimore, Md.
Captain, 308th Infantry,
77th Division.
Congressional Medal of Honor.
Volunteered to lead his company
in a hazardous attack on a commanding trench position near the
Aisne Canal, which other troops
had previously attempted to take
without success. His company immediately met with intense machinegun fire, against which it had no
artillery assistance, -but Captain
Miles preceded the first wave and
assisted in cutting a passage through
the enemy's wire entanglements. In
so doing he was wounded five times
by machine-gun bullets, both legs
and one arm being fractured;
whereupon, he ordered himself
carried forward to the enemy trench
in order that he might encourage
and direct his company, which by
this time ha:d suffered numerous
casualties. Under the inspiration
of this officer's indomitable spirit,
his men held the hostile position and
consolidated the front line after an
action lasting two hours, at the conclusion of which Captain Miles was
carried to the aid station against
his will.
"In concluding these brief exercises let our thoughts turn to those
who made the supreme sacrifice.
We would be untrue to • their
memory if we did not cherish with

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 15, 1929

GRADUATE STUDENT
DANCE TONIGHT
Tonight a Graduate Students' Dance will be held in
Levering Hall from nine to
twelve. Graduate students,
faculty members and their
wives are invited to.- attend.
A radical departure will be
adopted in the running of the
dance. No tickets for the
dance are being sold. Funds
to cover the expenses of the
dance will be collected indirectly. Boxes will be placed
at the doors and guests may
pay as they leave the hall.
This dance will be a forerunner to future affairs the graduate students have planned.

HARRIERS TO
RUN ST. JOHNS
Entry in Middle Atlantic Meet
Canceled
VICTORY EXPECTED
Sport New at Annapolis Instition
Since the Black and Blue's entry
into the Middle Atlantic CrossCountry meet has been called off
due to the ineligibility of Scheibel
and Packard, the Hopkins harriers
will meet the St. John's team this
Saturday instead. This arrangement will give the harriers a ten day
rest for the Maryland meet which
will take place Tuesday 26, at
Homewood field. The strength of
the St. John's team really cannot
be estimated, for this year they are
turning out their first regular team.
The meet will take place on the
Hopkins' four and one-half mile
course. It will start during the first
quarter of the St. Johns-Hopkins
football game and will end sometime between the halves. Kelly
says, "We expect the meet to be
over in twenty-seven minutes if possible." The football game together
with the harrier meet will make a
real St. John's-Hopkins day out of
this Saturday. Kelly expects the
same men to run who beat Catholic
University last week. Hancock
will probably be used if his foot
gets into shape by that• time.
The Saturday following St.
Johns will meet Maryland and two
days before Thanksgiving the Hopkins harriers will meet Maryland at
Hopkins. This will be the last
meet of the season for Hopkins and
Coach Hambleton is very hopeful
of the results. Maryland beat us
last year and we beat them the year
before. It has been alternating
thus for a number of years. This
year it is our turn to win if the
law of averages holds true. This
meet will be, it is expected, a replica of the conquest over the Catholic
University, for the boys know the
course and are still full of pep due
to the past victory.

EDITORIALS

VICTORY IN DEFEAT
we have allowed the football season to pass by without
U the customary
editorial exhorting the team to victory and all that
P to now

sort of thing. The reason should be obvious, for no mere words of
ours would have done the slightest bit of good. There is no use denying that this is an off year, that our football team has been competing
far out of its own class and, naturally, the results have been disastrous.
We must simply accept conditions as they are. Every college has one
or two famine seasons such as Hopkins is now passing through. The
coaches are helpless to change things and must use the material available to the best advantage even though the finished product may be
an uncoordinated machine.
As for the team itself, it probably feels its own incapabilities rather
seriously. To go into game after game and to be turned aside like
leaves in the path of an autumn wind is no cheerful experience. It
requires more pluck and,fight to go into a contest against opponents
whom you know to be far superior than to play on even footing. A
team, which week after week can play a fighting game in the face of
tremendous odds and yet not give way entirely, deserves some sort of
praise. We Americans are much too prone to hero worship. We
glorify the victor no matter how his victory was won and turn a "cold
shoulder" to the conquered victim. Yet often, the victor does not
deserve the praise as much as the victim who may, though losing,
gather more glory to himself than if he had won. We are not claim• ing glory for the Hopkins team, but only trying to make you realize
that our team, though it has lost all but one game and has had tremendous scores rolled up against it, nevertheless deserves praise for
fighting a losing battle gamely. It is no encouraging prospect for
those eleven men to go out every Saturday faced with a hopeless task.
Tomorrow, we meet an ancient rival who has a team, which, while
not equal to its best, is yet far superior in comparison with our own.
There is no use fooling ourselves that we will be, even approximately,
on an even footing with St. John's tomorrow afternoon. We can only
hope that the team will go out determined to fight as hard as it can
and play the best brand of football of which it is capable. No victory is expected, but Hopkins teams have a reputation for fighting hard
and making the best of all the "breaks" so that the unexpected is by
no means impossible.
More important than a victory is that the team shall play fairly and
squarely. We on the sidelines will be back of you in so far as our
vicarious participation may be of any help. What we most desire is
to see a good game. If you win we shall be happy in victory, but if
you lose, your defeat will not be any disgrace so long as you go down
fighting as onlyHopkins' teams can.

Regardless of the Editor's opinion of the journalistic talents which
I have exhibited in "pinch hitting"
for Gump, the editorial column of
a paper is no place to indulge in
purely personal attacks such as Mr.
Bloom permitted himself to do. My
editorial was purely a matter of attacking a policy which the Y.M.
C. A. has adopted and made no
reference to the individuals who are
responsible for this policy. I need
make no apologies for my literary
ability nor make any claims for it,
nor does the sarcasm of Mr. Bloom
affect me in the least. I haven't
noticed as yet that he has gathered
any laurels for himself as a critic
nor can I understand by what right
he presumes to set himself up as a
judge of anyone's ability. Whatever his personal opinions on the
subject may be, he is not privileged
to use the name of the "Y" as the
official champion of his views.
THE NEWS-LETTER is no battle
ground for mud-slinging, and I am
more than surprised that the supposedly gentlemanly members of
the Y. M. C. A. would permit their
paper in its official utterances, to
be used for any such unethical
purposes.

While you Seniors were shuffling worries
about machine stresses and saturation curves
with those of football last fall, a group of your
predecessors, not so many years ahead of you,
were playing the game with grim realities.
The Columbia Steel Company of Pittsburg,
California, completed plans on September 12th
to build a new tinplate plant. On the 13th
they gave an order to Westinghouse for two
5,000 horsepower synchronous motors to drive
the rolls, to be physically the largest synchronous motors ever built. Delivery of
the first was wanted in ninety days.
Ninety days in which to
design, manufacture, assem-

new achievement in size and type of construction, affords no time for idle speculation.
Westinghouse men went at the job as only an
experienced and thoroughly equipped organization could do. And on the scheduled date,
four flat cars and a box car rolled out of the
Westinghouse plant, carrying the completed
and tested motor.
It was an industrial victory, as satisfying as
any athletic gain. Teamwork and individual skill had won. Westinghouse had once
more made good and upheld the reputation that earns the big electrical jobs for Westinghouse men.
